data.q: Which method is used to select the first element that matches a specific CSS selector?
data.e: `querySelector()` is a powerful and flexible method that returns the first element within the document that matches the specified selector or group of selectors.

data.q: What is 'Event Bubbling' in the DOM?
o: When an event is triggered on all elements simultaneously
When an event starts at the target element and propagates up to its ancestors
When an event starts at the Document and moves down to the target
A method to delete multiple events at once
data.e: In the bubbling phase, the event first triggers on the target element and then bubbles up through its parents in the DOM tree.

data.q: Which method should you use to add a new child element to an existing parent element?
data.e: `appendChild()` adds a node to the end of the list of children of a specified parent node.

data.q: How can you prevent a click event on a link from navigating to a new URL?
data.e: `preventDefault()` cancels the event's default action (like following a link or submitting a form) without stopping further propagation of the event.

data.q: What is the primary difference between `innerText` and `textContent`?
o: innerText is for HTML; textContent is for plain text
innerText is aware of CSS styling (visibility); textContent is not
textContent is only supported in Internet Explorer
data.e: `innerText` returns only the 'human-readable' text (it won't return text hidden by CSS), while `textContent` returns the raw content of all elements, including `<script>` and `<style>` tags.

data.q: Which property allows you to read or set the HTML markup contained within an element?
data.e: `innerHTML` allows you to retrieve or replace the entire HTML structure inside an element as a string.

o: It prevents the default browser behavior
It prevents the event from bubbling up to parent elements
data.e: `stopPropagation()` stops the event from moving further up the DOM tree, ensuring parent event handlers are not triggered.

data.q: Which DOM property provides a live collection of an element's child elements?
data.e: `element.children` returns only the child nodes that are elements (tags), while `childNodes` includes text nodes and comments.

data.q: How do you correctly attach an event listener to an element so it can be easily removed later?
data.e: `addEventListener` is the modern standard; it allows multiple listeners for the same event and can be removed using `removeEventListener` if the handler is a named function.

o: The fastest way to download a JavaScript file
The sequence of steps the browser takes to convert HTML, CSS, and JS into actual pixels
The path of the mouse cursor across the screen
The hierarchy of file imports in a project
data.e: The Critical Rendering Path involves creating the DOM, CSSOM, Render Tree, Layout, and finally Painting.

o: It creates a 'lightweight' document that allows you to perform DOM operations off-screen for better performance
It creates a backup of the current page
It is used to parse JSON data
data.e: Document fragments are not part of the active DOM tree; changes made to them do not cause reflows, making them highly efficient for batch insertions.

data.q: Where is data stored if you use `window.localStorage`?
o: In the browser, with no expiration date
In the browser, but it's deleted when the tab is closed
data.e: `localStorage` stores data with no expiration date, meaning the data persists even after the browser is closed and reopened.
